Is there anything special about today's pictures that prompts me to write? No. Not really. Just an opportunity, on the shortest day of the year, which means starting tomorrow more light for us all, to say "Thank You'' for a whole year of images --- selected, curated, discussed and presented as never before for the photographer and amateur alike. Apparently California wasn't such a free society, since Mr. Underwood was subjected to psychological pressure to become a Christian.  I wonder how we can be freed from egregious propaganda in a free society?  It seems to me that "tolerance" has come to mean a sort of reflexive indifference to a great mass of passive people while meaning selective exceptionalism to both aggressive p.c. thought police and hypocritical libertarians.  I'm also old and remember the bad old days, but that was then and where we are now is very seriously not in it together anymore.  The "space" you refer to isn't the wide open ranges anymore.  I'm an Epicurean who has no use for any religion, but I sense a visceral prejudice in your comment.

Should not "Freedom of Religion" also be "Freedom from Religion?"
When I was in grammar school as i was called in those days, we sang religious songs at Christmas time. No matter that may of us were Jews. There was this psychological pressure to accept Jesus as our savior.

I have only recently become acquainted with Sikhs, and Muslims, but do not they and their children have the right to be free from religious propaganda?

Many years ago I was stationed in Massachusetts,. Being from California, I had no idea that local laws were predicated on some religious beliefs. It certainly was a culture shock to go from a free society, to one that promoted their christian views.

Certainly a religious institution should be allowed to hire only those of their own religion. But a nurse or doctor that serves the public, has no such right to refuse treatment base upon religious beliefs. That is inimitable to the well being of those who need these treatments. When one goes to the hospital for instance, one expects to get service from the staff, and not be subjected to religious discrimination. That is not freedom of religion from at least one side of the aisle.

You practice your religion in your space, and i will practice mine in my space.

Republicans, on the other hand, know that a vast amount of voters are low information people vulnerable to manipulation through misinformation, lies and emotional dog whistle coded rhetoric.

I wish I could remember the quote from a man in the 19th century, that Americans often do not resent the rich because they see themselves as that person, just temporarily inconvenienced in not having money.

Part of the problem for me is that this issue is too narrowly defined, as if there are just the rich and the not so rich. I've done well though I wouldn't consider myself wealthy, abiding by financial 'laws' learned mostly from my mother and dad, who went through the Great Depression. So frugality, getting a good education, working hard and doing your best were qualities to be emulated.

I have seen some people in my life who seem stubbornly resistant to taking education seriously, as if it is a silly waste of time, or those who may procrastinate or are content to do mediocre work. I understand that there are many people who work very hard, who strive for excellence and still may not do well financially.

It seems that there are many factors which determine one's success in life, at this time in my life, it is the hope to find more inner peace, and stop applying so much pressure to myself and some pressure I apply to others. It has much to do with what someone sees as fulfillment.

I don't like the gender specific marketing. Both my kids, girl, 14, and boy, 11, love lego, and love building house interiors and the like, with no stories. They have never named a minifig.
Why not just market to kids who like building planes and kids who like building houses etc. They tie ins with specific movies or other products limit it, in my mind. Even the city and creator sets have few or no female minifigs.
Why not have more open ended building that would appeal to kids who love to build and give them a more creative and open ended way to play?

As to the minifigs - At age 5, my daughter was frustrated that she had no female minifigs in her sets, so we searched the bins at a Lego store in Orlando - only to find one female charachter that was a keychain.
We've bought several sets since and if there are female minifigs, there are always fewer than the males.

The shape of the new 'girls' is problematic, in that the minifig shape is so iconic, it is sort of insulting that they feel like the girls need to be shaped so differently. definitely emphasizes body issues. The one belville set and figure we had was barely used.

Christmas has become increasingly expensive and stressful, so this year, I basically opted out. My family may be disappointed, but with the little disposable income I do have, I'm spending it on my son's tutoring. Nuff said. I'm glad that there are other people and families opting out too. I'm sure that massive consumerism and overspending are at the root of all of our financial problems.

Stand your ground JH. Your kids will be appreciative (eventually). My son and I have talked about how he's ONLY getting three things this year. Last year it was four. I always mention how Christmas is about family, NOT getting gifts that you don't need. Good luck!

In my family, only kids and parents get gifts. I get them inexpensive gifts ($5.00 - $20.00) but, hopefully,something that they like. There are other people in my family that keep to kid / parent rule but spend far more.

But the real reason I'm writing is to say that one of the best presents my parents ever got (so they say, anyway) was a Memory Jar. The woman who runs FlyLady.net (organization / declutter type information) posted the idea on her site.

All of my brothers, sisters, in-laws, etc. sent e-mails with one or two things that they remember about my parents. We wrote down each memory on colorful sheets of paper, folded them up into small squares and put them in a decorated coffee can.

It's been about five years since that Christmas and my parents say they take out the can full of memories to read whenever they feel like it. Once or twice, they read them when we are all together, so we all got to laugh at the funny memories and we all got to say "awww" at the heartfelt, emotional ones..

Anyway, it's a cheap gift that's nice to give and, apparently, get. Plus, it's clutter-free..

We limit the gifts for the adults to small and interesting. This year I bought a number of things that were made in Guatemala and were being sold as a fund-raiser by a friend who does volunteer conflict resolution workshops in Central America. She was selling these lovely little purses, necklaces, scarfs, etc to pay her airfare back to Guatemala. So these benefitted those who made and sold them to my friend, my friend toward her travel, and those who will benefit from the AVP workshops she will be facilitating.Fun and good stuff.

I can't ever remember making up stories for my Lego projects, but my sister usually did. Her mini people had names, and families, and histories. I just built houses and cities. We're both female.

This was back in the dark ages, when Lego sets were just bricks, with the occasional set of flowers, or fence pieces, or doors and windows, and the ever-coveted set of wheels, so if there was going to be any theme, it had to be created by us.

It might also be relevant to note that my sister is definitely the more artistic and creative one of the two of us, while I am much more logical and crafty.

My daughter will primarily have basic Lego to play with, as my mom kept the 20-gallon Rubbermaid tub full of Lego that was added to every Christmas. I won't say I'm against the themed sets, but I greatly prefer things that require imagination (and lack batteries!!)

I know someone who in the 4 years before he retired had an income of over $1,000,000 an hour.

Most of us do not hate anyone, but we do dislike certain people's behavior. Rich of course is relative, it all depends what rung of the ladder you are on. If you are living in the back woods, barely surviving on what little government subsidy you get, I might be considered rich to you.

On the other hand there are those I consider more than just rich, they are the wealthy. There are those who have houses where my whole house would fit in one room. There are those whose incomes can be $150,000 a day or more, just because they inherited several million shares of some big company. I consider them to be more than just wealthy. But I do not hate them. I do think however they are not paying their fair share for the upkeep of the country.

Nowhere else can someone accumulate that kind of wealth pay less for the protection of that wealth except in countries with corrupt governments. I do not hate them, but I consider them shirkers. Too many of them act as if he rest of us are just hanging around to deprive them of a few dollars, which they would not miss, but it seems to make them worry anyway.

What they do not seem to realize, is that if they do not help to fix the inequality, the resentment will build up over time, and there will be a movement to derive them of their wealth. instead of complaining about the march to Socialism, they need to get off their duffs and promote more equality, not try to stifle it. We believe that encouraging debate and engaging with fellow citizens is one of the most healthy and productive fundamentals of our democracy.
I'm a big Santorum fan, so just curious why you think he will do a lot better than pollsters predict?

All you Ron Paul fans should remember that he is not doing very well with registered Republicans. It is independents and fed up Democrats that are fueling his numbers. Once he gets to state primaries where only Republicans can vote, he is out of luck and out of votes. His foreign policy alone will sink him in closed primaries. As to Iowa, I think it is now safe to say that even a pollster as good as Nate will not be able to have any confidence in the outcome. It depends on so many factors outside the norm that it is a pollsters nightmare. At least the Republicans have a secret ballot at these caucuses in contrast to the Democrats who must (in front of their neighbors) say who they are for. It always made me chuckle as Democrats claim to be the party of the people but yet in some states they are forced to declare themselves in public, hardly very small d democratic. If I had to wager money (and certainly not $10,000) I think Romney is going to win Iowa by a hair. It also appears Santorum will do a lot better than the pollsters predict. If he beats Gingrich for 3rd place, Newt's best days are behind him which would leave the country a lot better off. A Romney-Obama contest will be a good show and a fair fight and will not involve a lot of extraneous nonsense that we have already seen in the preliminary action.
